awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Transparent Capture and Aggregation of Secure Data Provenance for Smart Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Computers are increasingly pervasive and diverse, embedded in devices ranging from smart phones and wearable computers to home automation devices and automotive systems. This explosive growth has far outpaced the speed with which device behaviors can be analyzed and understood, creating unprecedented opportunities for "Internet of Things" devices to engage in nefarious activities such as violating users' privacy or spreading malware. This project is designing and implementing new frameworks that track the provenance (i.e., history) of data processing and communications in systems of smart devices. To facilitate the identification of malicious behaviors, the project is developing non-invasive techniques for extracting device provenance, and presenting a public accountability infrastructure through which the history of interactions between smart devices can be analyzed.

In light of the great diversity of computing platforms in this environment, the efficient extraction of fine-grained data provenance is difficult. To overcome these challenges, the researchers are designing and implementing minimally-invasive mechanisms and associated algorithms for the observation of smart device activity at multiple system layers. The expected results include the development of a retrofit mechanism that leverages program instrumentation to enable complete provenance mediation for commodity-off-the-shelf smart devices, and a network mediation point that monitors inter-device communication in order to extract network provenance from systems of devices. Finally, the project is developing algorithms and protocols to securely extract and aggregate device provenance to a centralized repository, enabling provenance-based crowd-sourced monitoring of the Internet of Things. This work will not only establish foundations for trust in the functionality of smart devices, but also enable further research in provenance-based analytics.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet of Things (IoT) has become pervasive and diverse, integrating into our personal spaces and devices to create enhanced and automated experiences. Unfortunately, the explosive growth has far outpaced the speed with which device behaviors can be analyzed and understood, creating unprecedented opportunities for these devices to engage in nefarious activities. Many challenges impede our ability to effectively audit these problems; for example, these popular commodity IoT devices cannot be modified, nor do they have the resources to store audit logs for long periods.

This project designed and implemented new frameworks that enabled tracking of the provenance (i.e., history) of data processing and communications in systems of smart devices. Our goal was to facilitate the identification of malicious behaviors by first developing non-invasive techniques for extracting provenance from devices, then efficiently aggregating this information in a distributed accountability structure so that it could devices' actions could be analyzed.

This project has made significant progress towards assuring the transparency of Internet of Things devices. Through the funding this project received, we have built transparent mechanisms for auditing the activities of smart things. This includes a device-agnostic method for reconstructing the actions of cooperating devices and applications in a smart home. We have also developed a method to reason about the information flows within home automation logic based on natural language analysis. This technique is fully transparent; in other words, no device or application access is required. Further, we have design a highly efficient technique for aggregating the audit logs of different IoT devices. Our approach built a "grammar" for describing the activities of each device, then identified redundancies between devices to dramatically reduce the amount of audit log information that needs to be transmitted and stored.

Beyond this work, this project led to a variety of additional investigations related to the security and privacy of smart devices, including;

  • We analyzed the potential for speech recognition errors made by IoT Voice Assistants to be weaponized by attackers, demonstrating that it was possible to "squat" on words close to the name of a popular app in order to gain access to users' devices. This vulnerability was disclosed and acknowledged to the affected vendors. 
  • We also conducted an analysis of the privacy protection mechanisms of popular mobile fitness tracking applications, discovering that up to 95% of athletes that used these features to protect the location of their home address were at risk. This vulnerability was also disclosed to several of the affected companies, who used our proposed mitigation to improve the real-world privacy of millions of users. 
  • Additionally, we also designed novel techniques for efficiently auditing UAV drones' compliance with "No Fly Zone" areas. Given the tremendous public concern over their privacy implications of drones, this advancement demonstrates an honest and accountable path forward for the use of this technology.

This work has also had significant training impact. Four students who were funded through this project are currently making progress towards obtaining PhDs. These students are on track to be placed in research positions in academia and industry where they will continue to investigate challenges related to the security and privacy of smart devices.
